The map translation module is designed for estimating real world positions of vehicular traffic based on the in frame pixel coordinates of the source video.
In order to translate the frame coordinates into map coordinates, points of references were used.

In both the frame coordinates and the real world coordinates (lat, long), 8 points of references were taken. These points were marked and used as anchor points to calculate the movement of the vehicles and translate it into estimated real world coordinates.

As shown in the image above, the coordinates divide the shape into four main quadrants. Depending on the quadrant that the vehicle is in, the sign for the operation to calculate the real world coordinate will change (negative or positive).

The process overall is straight foward. Suppose the vehicle is currentl in Q1, at location (x_i, y_i). We can use the reference point A, call it (x_a, y_b), and its known translation to lat and lng, call it (lat_a, lat_b), with a following reference point B, to calculate a x and y ratio using the following equation:
In code, this was expressed as:
This ratio is then multiplied by the current in frame coordinates to achieve the location in the map. In code this, was done as follows:

The overall code application is divided into server-client structure. The front end code is written in basic js and leaflet js, following the common js setup structure while python with the socket library is used to send udp packets to the front end. The basic flow of data is show as follows:

This repository contains files relevant to a project intended for use for traffic monitoring for Guyana.

The project seeks to address the high intensity of traffic related congestion and incidents, through the use of computer vision technology. This intends to monitor the flow of traffic and relay data of traffic flow, density, etc through a web application.
